[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: random_g1_points()] [Memory exhaustion] Since G1Projective is 96 bytes, can attackers request n values causing GB allocations (n=10^7 = ~960MB) to crash validators? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: random_g1_points()] [Point uniqueness] Are all generated points guaranteed to be unique, or could hash-to-curve collisions (though cryptographically negligible) cause duplicate points in DKG commitments? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: random_g1_points()] [Vector reallocation] If with_capacity(n) underestimates and the vector grows, can reallocation during push() cause performance degradation exploitable for timing attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: random_g2_points()] [Extreme performance cost] At 150μs per point, generating n=1000 points takes 150ms - is this acceptable during DKG, or can attackers force timeouts by triggering large G2 vector generation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: random_g2_points()] [Memory size] G2Projective is 192 bytes - can n=10^6 cause ~192MB allocations exceeding validator memory limits during DKG? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_gt_points()] [Batch discrete log exposure] Does this function leak all n discrete logs, and if used in production, can attackers efficiently extract all scalars to break DKG security? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_gt_points()] [Performance DoS] At 507μs per GT point, generating n=100 takes 50ms - combined with the security warning, is this ever called in hot paths causing both performance and security issues? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Predictable pattern] The points are generated as acc = acc.double() + shift deterministically - can attackers predict all n points after observing just 2-3 points, completely breaking DKG randomness assumptions? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Production misuse] Is this function clearly marked as benchmarking-only, or could it accidentally be used in production DKG code causing catastrophic predictability of commitment points? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Linear relationship] Since each point is acc_{i+1} = 2*acc_i + shift, can linear algebra attacks recover the initial point and shift, then predict all future points in the sequence? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Small group order] If the doubling operation cycles through a small subgroup, could the sequence repeat after k points (k < n) causing duplicate commitments in DKG? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Shift value security] If the 'shift' point is weak (e.g., low order), does the entire sequence inherit this weakness making all n points vulnerable? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g1_points()] [Performance vs security tradeoff] The comment says this is 'faster' - have benchmarks confirmed this, and is the speed gain (maybe 2-3x) worth the complete security loss if misused? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g2_points()] [G2 pattern predictability] Does the same linear relationship acc = acc.double() + shift apply to G2, and can attackers exploit identical vulnerabilities to predict G2 commitment points? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/utils/random.rs] [Function: insecure_random_g2_points()] [Cross-group attacks] If G1 and G2 use the same deterministic pattern, can attackers leverage pairing equations to break DKG security even if one group is random? (High)
